Package dev.kkorolyov.simpleprops

Class Properties

  • java.lang.Object
    • dev.kkorolyov.simpleprops.Properties
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.lang.Iterable<java.util.Map.Entry<java.lang.String,java.lang.String>>

    public final class Properties
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.lang.Iterable<java.util.Map.Entry<java.lang.String,java.lang.String>>
    A collection of key-value pairs, comments, and blank lines which maintain original insertion order.

      • iterator

        public java.util.Iterator<java.util.Map.Entry<java.lang.String,java.lang.String>> iterator​()
        Returns an iterator over all properties in original insertion order. The values of individual properties iterated over can be modified, though removing properties with Iterator.remove() has no effect.
        Specified by:
        iterator in interface java.lang.Iterable<java.util.Map.Entry<java.lang.String,java.lang.String>>
        Returns:
        iterator over properties, in insertion order

      • put

                            java.lang.String... values)

        values - property values
        Returns:

      • put

        public int put​(Properties other,
               boolean overwrite)
        Copies all properties from another Properties instance to this instance. If this instance is completely empty (no properties nor filler), all values from other are copied to this instance.
        Parameters:
        other - instance providing properties
        overwrite - if true, properties found both in this instance and in other, will have their values overwritten by those in other
        Returns:
        number of appended and overwritten properties

      • remove

        public java.lang.String remove​(java.lang.String key)
        Removes the property identified by key.
        Parameters:
        key - identifier of property to remove
        Returns:
        removed property's value, or null if no such property

        public boolean equals​(java.lang.Object obj)
        Compares this object to another for equality. To be equal, obj must be an instance of Properties and have a set of properties identical to this instance's set.
